Matthew Poole's commentary on Ezekiel 38 presents a complex symbolic vision where Gog represents a formidable, multi-national coalition of opposition against God's people, extending beyond historical Seleucids or Scythian/Turkic forces to encompass future antichristian alliances and global threats. Poole emphasizes that Gog is not a single historical figure but a composite symbol of persistent, organized opposition—whether historical powers like Antiochus Epiphanes or later confederations of northern heathen nations—intentionally warning the Jewish community of future trials amid their restoration. Theologically, this passage underscores God's sovereign control over hostile forces, revealing that even the most formidable armies (horses, shields, swords) will be turned back by divine intervention, affirming that God's judgment is not arbitrary but purposeful. Crucially, Poole connects this prophecy to Christ: the ultimate defeat of Gog's forces prefigures Christ's victory over sin, death, and all opposing powers, where the "army of Gog" symbolizes the final rebellion against God's kingdom that Christ will decisively overcome. Practically, this commentary calls believers to vigilance against modern spiritual and political threats—recognizing that the "army of Gog" manifests in contemporary movements seeking to undermine faith or God's church. It encourages steadfast readiness in spiritual warfare, trusting that Christ's authority, not human strength, will prevail, urging Christians to remain alert and faithful despite pervasive opposition, knowing God's ultimate victory is secured through Christ. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Ezekiel 38 presents this chapter as a prophetic vision of a final global conflict where God's people face a coalition of nations led by the north-oriented figure Gog—a symbol of organized, evil opposition rising against Israel's restoration. Barnes emphasizes this prophecy occurs *after* Israel's restoration, depicting a "last conflict of the world with God" where Gog's forces, a gathering of enemies from diverse regions (Ethiopia, Libya, Scythians, etc.), march against the land of Israel to plunder its security. Theologically, Barnes underscores that this vision reveals God's sovereign judgment against persistent rebellion, where divine wrath ("overflowing rain," "fire," and "brimstone") purifies the earth, ultimately sanctifying God's people by demonstrating His holiness through the destruction of evil. Crucially, Barnes connects this to Christ: Gog's defeat signifies the ultimate triumph of Christ over sin and death, as the prophecy's climax points to the "sanctification in thee" (Gog) where God's justice is revealed, mirroring Christ's victory over the final enemy. Practically, Christians are called to avoid the pride and self-sufficiency of Gog—preparing for God's protection rather than seeking power—while living in unity and hope, knowing that God's judgment precedes His redemption. This vision thus serves as a reminder that true security comes not from human strength but from Christ's victory, urging believers to remain steadfast in faith as they anticipate the ultimate restoration of God's kingdom. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Ezekiel 39 emphasizes God's decisive judgment on the future enemy Gog, culminating in the complete destruction of his forces and the purification of Israel's land. Henry interprets this as a divine act where God's holy name is publicly revealed through the devastation of Gog's army—a powerful demonstration of His sovereignty over all earthly powers. Theologically, this prophecy functions as a type of Christ's final judgment, where God's wrath against sin and rebellion is fulfilled, yet it simultaneously points to His redemptive mercy. The "cleansing" described in verses 11–22—where the land is purified through the burial of enemies and the active participation of the people in restoration—symbolizes the spiritual purification Israel undergoes when they turn from sin. Crucially, Henry connects this passage to Christ's fulfillment: the sacrificial feast for animals (verses 17–21) prefigures the New Covenant where Christ's blood provides eternal cleansing, and the promise of God's Spirit being "poured out" on Israel (verse 29) directly echoes the Pentecost event. Practically, this commentary calls Christians to active holiness—engaging in repentance, diligent pursuit of righteousness, and participation in God's redemptive work. Just as the people of Israel were instructed to cleanse the land after Gog's defeat, believers must diligently seek to eradicate sin in their lives and communities, recognizing that God's judgment on evil (Gog) and His mercy toward the redeemed (Israel) are inseparable. This passage thus urges a life of obedience that anticipates Christ's return, where God's people will experience His presence and glory through steadfast faith and transformative obedience. (248 words)

Calvin viewed Ezekiel 39 as a profound divine promise of ultimate restoration and purification, where the figure of Gog symbolizes the pervasive cosmic enemy threatening God's people. His commentary emphasizes that God's judgment on Gog—turning him back, scattering his forces, and reducing him to the earth—represents the final defeat of all opposition to God's kingdom. Theologically, Calvin highlighted that this passage reveals God's sovereign authority: He will cleanse Israel through the burial of Gog's remains in the valley of Hamongog, ensuring the land's spiritual renewal and the restoration of His holy name. Crucially, Calvin connected this to Christ, seeing Gog as a prefiguration of the ultimate adversary who will be vanquished by Christ's victory. The "feast" described for all creatures—where they consume the flesh and blood of the mighty—foreshadows the Lord's Supper, where Christ's body and blood are spiritually consumed by believers, signifying participation in His redemptive work. Practically, Calvin urged believers to embrace this promise: trust God's ultimate victory over all enemies, actively participate in communal repentance and purification (as symbolized by the seven-month cleansing period), and live in confident expectation of Christ's return. This passage calls for spiritual renewal through Christ, where the shame of exile is transformed into joyous restoration, ensuring God's holy name is no longer polluted but glorified among nations.

Matthew Poole's commentary on Ezekiel 39 presents a profound theological vision where Gog symbolizes future Gentile opposition against God's people, culminating in divine judgment that purifies Israel. Poole interprets God's action against Gog—reducing his forces, rendering his weapons useless, and scattering his army across Israel—as a decisive demonstration of God's sovereignty over all enemies. The destruction of Gog's army, the burning of weapons for seven years, and the burial of the slain without ritual observance underscore a radical shift: God's holiness is now revealed among His people, ending the profanation of His name through idolatry and sin. Crucially, Poole connects this prophecy to Christ, seeing Gog as a prophetic figure representing the ultimate enemy of God's kingdom—those who oppose Christ and His church—while the "feast of the slain" prefigures Christ's atoning death and resurrection. Theologically, this passage reveals God's justice and mercy: He judges the wicked to uphold His holiness while restoring His people with a renewed covenant. Practically, it calls believers to reject militaristic solutions, trust God's protection in times of conflict, and participate in communal worship that honors His name. The seven-year burning of weapons symbolizes the irreversible end of war for the believer, urging active engagement in spiritual renewal rather than worldly vengeance. For modern readers, this text reminds us that God's ultimate victory over all opposition—whether historical or contemporary—rests on Christ's work, empowering believers to live in peace and holiness by centering their lives on the Lord rather than external threats. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Ezekiel 39 reveals this chapter as a profound symbolic prophecy of divine judgment and restoration, not a historical account. The prophet's vision of Gog's defeat—where his army is scattered, his weapons destroyed, and his remains buried in the valley of Hamon-Gog—signifies God's ultimate triumph over evil forces and the purification of His people. Barnes emphasizes that this "figure" avoids literal interpretation, stressing that the land's cleansing through the seven-month burial process symbolizes the spiritual purification of the Church, where sin's consequences are removed to restore holiness. Theologically, this passage underscores God's sovereignty: He actively dismantles opposition (Gog representing rebellion), ensures the holy name is honored through the people's renewed obedience, and establishes His presence among all nations. Crucially, Barnes connects the sacrificial feast described in verses 17-20—where all creatures partake of the "flesh of the mighty"—to Christ as the true fulfillment. This meal anticipates the New Covenant where believers consume Christ's body and blood, experiencing divine reconciliation and full restoration. Practically, this prophecy calls Christians to actively resist spiritual "Gog" (evil systems and sin), embrace the cleansing work of Christ's sacrifice, and understand that God's judgment on past iniquity precedes His mercy and restoration. It challenges believers to live with confidence in God's final victory, knowing that His presence among the redeemed ensures the holy name is no longer polluted, and that true restoration comes through Christ's work, not human effort. This vision remains a powerful reminder of God's active care for His people. (248 words)

Henry observes that Ezekiel's vision in chapter 40 presents a meticulously detailed, yet complex, blueprint of the future temple during the prophet's captivity. This intricate description—featuring precise measurements with a reed, gates with specific dimensions, chambers, arches, palm trees, and eight sacrificial tables—reveals God's sovereign order and perfect design for His people. Theologically, Henry emphasizes that this vision transcends mere architectural detail; it symbolizes Christ as the true "Altar and Sacrifice" where divine reconciliation occurs. The brass figure measuring the temple represents Christ's authority to define God's kingdom, while the sacrificial tables prefigure the New Covenant where Christ's atoning blood replaces the old system. Crucially, Henry connects the temple's central role as "Salvation in the midst of the earth" (Psalm 74:12) to Christ's presence as the living temple where believers encounter God. Practically, this vision challenges believers to move beyond ritualism and see Christ as the only true temple—where all access to God is secured through His sacrifice. It calls for humility, as the vision reveals God's meticulous care for His people's needs, encouraging trust in His faithful provision rather than human efforts. Like the measuring reed, Christ's perfect atoning work provides the precise standard for reconciliation, inviting believers to "declare all that [they] see" by trusting Him as the ultimate sacrifice and dwelling place, fulfilling the promise that salvation is found in Him alone. This vision thus points to Christ as the living temple where believers find their true identity and access to God. (248 words)

Calvin observed that Ezekiel's detailed vision of the restored temple complex in chapter 40 functions as a profound theological revelation, not merely a physical blueprint but a divine instruction for Israel's spiritual restoration. The meticulous measurements—using a reed of six cubits—symbolize God's precise, covenantal order and His unwavering presence among His people despite their sin. The brass man with the measuring reed represents Christ Himself, the ultimate standard of divine truth and judgment, while the palm trees on the temple posts signify Christ's eternal presence and the spiritual nourishment of His followers. Calvin emphasized that the intricate design—eight-step gates, chambers for priests, and tables for sacrifices—reveals God's intimate care for His people's worship and atonement, pointing directly to Christ as the true Temple where sin is forgiven. Theologically, this vision underscores that God's covenant remains faithful even when His people are exiled, fulfilling His promise through the Messiah. Practically, Calvin urged believers to seek Christ's guidance in their worship lives, recognizing that true holiness requires alignment with God's precise standards of love and justice, not ritualistic formality. The vision's Christ connection is explicit: the temple's purpose—to provide a place of fellowship and sacrifice—finds its fulfillment in Christ, who is the "true temple" (John 2:19) and the sole mediator between God and humanity (1 Timothy 2:5). For modern believers, this passage calls for humility in worship, reliance on Christ's atoning work, and an active participation in the spiritual community where God's presence dwells, transforming how we understand our identity in Christ and the nature of true worship. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Ezekiel 40 reveals a profound visionary encounter where God, through the Spirit, guides Ezekiel to a detailed model of Jerusalem's temple, emphasizing divine sovereignty and meticulous restoration. Poole notes the precise timing—this vision occurred on the tenth day of Nisan, aligning with Passover preparations—highlighting God's intentional sequencing in Israel's redemption. The man with the brass-like appearance and plumbline (a "line of flax" for rectitude) is explicitly identified by Poole as Christ, "The Branch" from Zechariah 6, who measures the temple with a reed of six cubits (symbolizing divine precision and Christ's sufficiency). Theodicy emerges: the vision shows God's meticulous care for Israel's restoration after exile, where the temple's dimensions—thick walls, uniform gates, and chambers—reflect divine order and the covenant community's structure. Practically, this calls believers to meditate with "hearts set upon all" revelation, avoiding superficial interpretation while trusting God's standard. Poole stresses that the reed, held by Christ alone, signifies that true measurement of spiritual life and church order comes through Christ, not human effort. Theologically, the temple model becomes a living symbol of Christ's presence: the "house" represents the church, the gates the boundaries of faith, and the measuring reed Christ's authority to define spiritual truth. This vision thus challenges believers to live with disciplined precision in worship, embrace Christ as the sole standard for spiritual life, and understand that God's restoration of Israel foreshadows His ultimate renewal of all things through Christ—the only true measure of divine righteousness. (248 words)

Barnes interprets Ezekiel 40 as a profound symbolic vision depicting God's future restoration of His kingdom, not a blueprint for physical rebuilding. He emphasizes that the meticulous details—square courts, precise measurements, and the city's layout—carry deep theological meaning, representing divine order, harmony, and the perfected worship of Christ's kingdom. Crucially, Barnes argues this vision transcends the post-exilic context, pointing instead to Christ's future rule where God's presence dwells among His people through the New Covenant. The absence of the high priest and specific rituals underscores that Christ's single atoning sacrifice has fulfilled the old order, rendering the temple's physical structures symbolic rather than functional. The vision's symbolic framework—where the temple signifies God's dwelling, the priesthood mediates, and the monarchy reflects Christ's sovereign rule—reveals that true restoration involves a renewed relationship with God, not mere territorial or institutional renewal. Practically, this encourages believers to focus on living out Christ's kingdom through consistent, daily worship and service, rather than fixating on external rituals or political restoration. The jubilee year context (Ezekiel 40:1) further highlights God's promise of restoration in the present, reminding us that His kingdom operates through grace and righteousness. Ultimately, Barnes' analysis shows that this vision anticipates Christ's reign where the "oblation" for the priesthood and city becomes the believer's daily offering to God, fostering a community where worship flows from intimate communion with the risen Lord rather than ritualistic observance.

Matthew Henry's commentary on Ezekiel 41 emphasizes how the meticulous measurements of the temple's sacred spaces reveal God's precise and ordered kingdom, serving as a divine blueprint for believers. Henry interprets the "most holy place" (41:5) not merely as a physical structure but as a spiritual reality symbolizing Christ's presence and the intimate relationship between God and His people. The detailed descriptions—cherubim, palm trees, and architectural precision—highlight theological insights: God's kingdom operates with divine order, where righteousness and holiness are meticulously maintained, reflecting Christ's role as the perfect mediator who reconciles humanity to God. Practically, Henry urges believers to attend closely to Scripture's clearer teachings, as the prophet's careful measurement leads deeper into understanding God's mysteries, encouraging disciplined spiritual observation and alignment with divine truth. Crucially, Henry connects this temple imagery to Christ: the "most holy place" prefigures Christ's heavenly sanctuary, where He intercedes (Hebrews 9:24), and the cherubim symbolize Christ's divine presence and protection, while the palm trees point to His righteousness and the tree of life. This chapter thus reveals that true worship and access to God are mediated through Christ's atoning work, calling believers to seek Him with the precision of the temple's design—living in ordered righteousness, trusting in Christ's completed work, and finding their eternal dwelling in Him rather than in human structures. (248 words)

Calvin emphasized that Ezekiel's detailed temple measurements in chapter 41 function as a divine blueprint revealing God's ordered sovereignty and the intimate connection between earthly worship and Christ's fulfillment. He interpreted the precise cubit dimensions—particularly the "most holy place" (20x20 cubits) and the winding, ascending structure of the side chambers—as symbolic of God's meticulous governance over His people and the progressive nature of spiritual growth. The cherubim and palm trees, especially the "man-faced" cherubim facing palm trees, signified Christ's dual nature: the humanity (the "man") and the divine (the lion), united in the temple's design. Theologically, Calvin saw this vision as a profound declaration that God's presence is not confined to physical structures but dwells within the believer through the Holy Spirit, the true "most holy place" where Christ's work reconciles us to God. Practically, this calls believers to reject superficial religious rituals and instead cultivate inner devotion—measuring their spiritual life by obedience, humility, and the presence of Christ within, not external measurements. Christ is the ultimate fulfillment of this vision: His incarnation fulfills the temple's purpose, becoming the "most holy place" where divine and human nature unite. Thus, the church's true vocation is to live in Christ's presence, where spiritual growth is measured by faithfulness to Him, not by physical dimensions, transforming our lives into living temples of God's glory. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Ezekiel 41 presents a meticulous measurement of the temple's structure, emphasizing divine precision in God's sanctuary design. He details the temple's walls as six cubits thick (equivalent to the tabernacle's breadth), the holy of holies as a perfect square (twenty cubits by twenty cubits), and the side chambers that progressively widen upward—from five to seven cubits—reflecting a theological principle of expanding accessibility to God's presence. Poole underscores that the holy of holies, where the mercy-seat resided, represents the ultimate sphere of divine encounter, distinct from the outer courts and chambers. Theologically, this precise geometry reveals God's intention for His people: a sanctuary where His presence is both intimate and constrained by holiness, requiring careful stewardship. Crucially, Poole connects these measurements to Christ, whose body is the true temple (John 2:19-21), where the "holy of holies" becomes the indwelling presence of the Holy Spirit. The widening chambers symbolize the growing capacity for believers to receive Christ's grace as they deepen their relationship with Him, while the temple's walls—narrow at the base but widening inward—mirror how faith grows from humility to expanded fellowship with God. Practically, this commentary encourages believers to view their spiritual lives as spaces of intentional growth, where initial narrowness (like the temple's foundation) gradually expands to accommodate Christ's transformative presence. It calls for humility in approaching God's holiness while actively cultivating the "wider chambers" of spiritual maturity through Christ's work, ensuring that worship remains both reverent and expansive. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Ezekiel 41 reveals a meticulously measured temple vision where precise dimensions symbolize divine order and holiness. The prophet's detailed accounting—six-cubit walls, twenty-cubit chambers, and a corridor ("place that was left") separating side chambers from the temple—highlights God's intentional design for sacred space. Theologically, this structure reflects the Church as God's dwelling place: the outer court represents the community of believers, the holy place signifies worship and fellowship, while the most holy place (the "oracle") points to Christ's presence as the true and only access to God. Barnes emphasizes that the temple's reorganization—like the corridor—shows God's emphasis on separation between holiness and human sinfulness, requiring Christ's mediation. Practically, this vision urges believers to cultivate clear boundaries in worship and community, avoiding the mixing of sacred and profane. The corridor's five-cubit width, where side chambers open, becomes a potent metaphor for the narrow path through Christ—only He bridges the chasm between divine holiness and human fallibility. Christologically, the temple's "most holy place" directly corresponds to Christ's body (the Church), while the sacrificial waste area (the "separate place") foreshadows Christ's atoning work that purifies the community from sin's defilement. This vision thus challenges believers to live with disciplined reverence, recognizing that true access to God is mediated through Christ alone—a truth that sustains worship, ethical living, and the hope of restoration in an imperfect world. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Ezekiel 42 presents the priests' chambers as a profound theological symbol within the temple complex, emphasizing their sacred purpose and precise spatial relationship to the holy space. Henry notes these chambers—described as fifty cubits long and positioned near the temple—were specifically for the priests to handle the most holy offerings, acting as a transitional holy place where they prepared their garments before entering the main sanctuary. Theologically, Henry connects this intricate design to Christ as the true Temple: just as the temple's structure accommodated many priests in holy service, Christ declares, "In my Father's house are many mansions" (John 14:2), indicating a vast, accessible reality of divine presence for believers. The chambers' dimensions and separation from the profane area symbolize how Christ, the ultimate sanctuary, provides intimate, dedicated spaces for spiritual preparation and communion with God, ensuring that worship remains holy and focused. Practically, Henry stresses that our private spiritual life must actively prepare us for public service in the church community—just as the priests prepared their garments in the chambers before entering the holy place. This means cultivating disciplined, dedicated worship practices in our personal faith that align with Christ's sacrificial work, ensuring we approach God's presence with purity and readiness. The chapter ultimately reveals that Christ's presence in the heavenly sanctuary provides the space and authority for believers to live holy lives, where the true temple of God is not a physical structure but the indwelling Spirit, inviting us to dwell in His holiness through faith.

Calvin observed that Ezekiel's detailed description of the north-facing chambers in the temple complex—specifically their holy function for priestly rituals, the strict separation from the profane areas, and the precise measurements—reveals profound theological truths about the nature of divine holiness and its necessary access. He emphasized that these chambers symbolize the exclusive space where priests handle the most sacred offerings, requiring ritual purification and a distinct separation from the common area. This structure underscores God's requirement for a purified approach to the divine: true worship demands internal cleansing and a conscious separation from sin, as the priests must change garments before entering the people's space. Calvin connected this to Christ as the ultimate fulfillment of this vision, explaining that Christ's body is the new sanctuary where the Holy Spirit dwells, and His atoning work replaces the old temple rituals. The chambers' strict rules—where priests cannot leave the holy place without proper preparation—point to the necessity of spiritual regeneration before encountering God's presence. Practically, this means believers must actively pursue inner purification through Christ's work, recognizing that genuine participation in worship requires a transformed heart, not merely external observance. The 500 reed walls separating the sanctuary from profane areas symbolize the new covenant where Christ's blood creates a permanent separation from sin, urging Christians to maintain spiritual boundaries through ongoing faith and repentance, ensuring their approach to God remains holy and transformative. (248 words)

Poole's commentary on Ezekiel 42 provides a meticulous architectural analysis of the temple's "utmost court" and associated chambers, emphasizing their precise measurements and spatial relationships. He interprets this section as revealing God's intricate divine order within the temple complex—specifically the priests' court, chambers facing north with galleries in three stories, a fifty-cubit wall, and the hundred-cubit space before the temple. Theologically, Poole underscores that this detailed vision transcends mere physical structure; it portrays God's covenantal precision and sovereignty over His people. The chambers, positioned between the temple and the "separate place," symbolize the intimate yet distinct relationship between God's people and His dwelling, reflecting the necessity of holiness while acknowledging human sinfulness. Practically, this vision calls believers to cultivate humility before God's meticulous design in creation and redemption, recognizing that true worship requires alignment with His standards rather than human convenience. Crucially, Poole connects this earthly temple imagery to Christ—viewing the "separate place" as a prefiguration of Christ's atoning work and the chambers as the new covenant community dwelling within the heavenly temple. For modern readers, this commentary illuminates that Christ is the true "temple" (Ephesians 2:18–22), where the Spirit dwells and believers are reconciled. It challenges Christians to live with disciplined faith, understanding that God's covenant promises are both deeply personal and profoundly communal, anchored in the perfection of Christ's sacrifice. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on Ezekiel 42 reveals the precise spatial design of the temple's holy chambers, emphasizing their critical role as the priests' dedicated sanctuary for handling sacred rites. These north-facing chambers, measuring 100 cubits long and 50 cubits wide with three terraced stories, functioned as the "holy place" where priests prepared and consumed the most holy offerings—meat, sin, and trespass sacrifices—after the altar. Barnes underscores their profound sanctity: priests entered here to perform rituals, changed garments, and maintained strict separation from the outer court, highlighting how God's design required intentional boundaries between sacred and profane acts. Theologically, this vision illuminates God's meticulous provision for holiness, showing that true worship demands dedicated, purified spaces where ritual purity meets divine presence. Practically, it challenges believers to cultivate intentional sacred spaces within their lives—separating worship practices from everyday routines to honor God's holiness. Crucially, Barnes connects these chambers to Christ as the ultimate fulfillment: the temple's sacrificial system pointed to Christ, who becomes the true "holy place" (Hebrews 9:24) where atonement is accomplished. The priests' ritual purity, once confined to physical chambers, now finds its eternal significance in Christ's once-for-all sacrifice, where believers approach God through Him, not ritual structures. This ancient vision thus reveals that Christ is the living sanctuary where true holiness and reconciliation are achieved.

Matthew Henry's commentary on Ezekiel 43 presents a vision of God's restored presence within the temple after Israel's exile, emphasizing God's covenant faithfulness despite their past disobedience. Henry interprets this scene as a profound theological declaration: the glory of God returning signifies His renewed commitment to dwell with His people, contingent upon their repentance and obedience. Crucially, Henry connects this vision to Christ's ultimate fulfillment, noting that while the temple rituals described—like the purification of the altar with blood sacrifices—were necessary for Israel's restoration, they point forward to Christ, who "by one offering" perfected believers for eternal communion with God (Hebrews 10:14). The blood of Christ, Henry argues, becomes the sole and sufficient cleansing for sin, replacing the animal sacrifices that only temporarily covered transgressions. Practically, this passage calls believers to heartfelt repentance before God, as the vision demands Israel "be ashamed of their iniquities" and embrace the "whole form" of God's law. For modern readers, it underscores that true worship and fellowship with God are only accessible through Christ's atoning work, not human rituals. The altar's meticulous specifications, especially the repeated emphasis on blood purification, illustrate that spiritual cleansing requires the blood of the Lamb—Christ's sacrifice—applying to all sin, past and present. This vision thus serves as a powerful reminder: our access to God is secured by Christ's finished work, and genuine spiritual renewal demands repentance, obedience to His law, and participation in the ongoing work of the Holy Spirit who applies Christ's sacrifice to the believer's life.

Calvin interpreted Ezekiel 43 as a profound revelation of God's restored presence and the covenant promise fulfilled through Christ. He emphasized that the "glory of the Lord" entering the temple (v.2-5) symbolized Christ's ascension and the indwelling of the Holy Spirit, contrasting the previous desolation with the promise of eternal dwelling. For Calvin, the detailed instructions for the altar and purification rituals (v.13-27) were not mere ceremonial but vivid foreshadowings of Christ's atoning work: the blood purification (v.20) prefigures the New Covenant in Christ's shed blood, while the seven-day consecration (v.25-26) mirrors the process of spiritual cleansing through Christ's redemption. Theologically, Calvin underscored that God's dwelling among Israel (v.7) is conditional on repentance and obedience—renewing the covenant through the faithful priesthood (v.19-20), which Christ ultimately fulfills as the true high priest. Practically, this calls believers to examine their lives against sin (v.8-9), actively repent, and live by the covenant's commands—not as legalistic rituals but as participation in Christ's redemption. The temple's restoration, Calvin argued, signifies Christ's victory over sin and death, urging the church to embrace the fullness of God's presence through faith in Christ alone, where the true "house" is the believer's spiritual dwelling in Him. This passage, therefore, anchors believers in the reality that God's covenant promise is secured by Christ's sacrifice, demanding both repentance and faithful obedience to live in His restored kingdom.

Matthew Poole's commentary on Ezekiel 43 reveals a profound theological vision of God's restored presence following Israel's exile. Poole emphasizes that the return of God's glory to the temple after a period of forty-six years (spanning Cyrus, Cambyses, and Darius) signifies divine covenant faithfulness despite persistent idolatry. The glory's arrival from the east—where it had departed—symbolizes God's active restoration of His dwelling place among the people. Crucially, Poole identifies the "man" standing by the prophet as Christ, the Mediator who enables God's presence and communication. Theologically, this vision underscores that God's dwelling in the temple (a type of His church) is conditional upon Israel's repentance from defiling His name through idolatry, sacrilege, and the corruption of worship. Poole connects the temple's restoration to the New Covenant, where Christ's atoning work enables true holiness. Practically, this calls believers to actively abandon idolatry—both external practices and internal sin—by rejecting the "carcasses of kings" (idolatrous practices) and the "high places" of false worship. The promise that God will dwell "for ever" in the midst of the repentant community offers hope for enduring transformation. For modern readers, this means embracing Christ as the living temple where God's presence dwells through faith, actively pursuing spiritual purity, and recognizing that genuine restoration requires radical repentance and a commitment to holiness that honors God's name in daily life. The vision thus bridges ancient prophecy with the believer's call to live in the presence of a faithful God. (248 words)

Barnes emphasizes that Ezekiel 43 reveals the profound theological shift in God's presence during the new temple's consecration, where the divine glory—once veiled in cloud over the mercy-seat—now manifests dynamically within the sanctuary. This glory, appearing as living cherubim and a rainbow, signifies God's personal, active dwelling rather than a static dwelling-place, directly contrasting the destroyed temple of Solomon and the ark's absence, which Barnes interprets as the prefiguration of Christ's final sacrifice replacing the old covenant. Theologically, this passage underscores God's exclusive holiness and the necessity of repentance: the house of Israel must cease defiling His name through idolatry and the dead kings' remains, as their actions had previously polluted the sacred space. Practically, it demands humble obedience—shame for past iniquity, active repentance, and meticulous adherence to God's ordinances, as the temple's pattern serves as a blueprint for restoring relational health with the divine. Crucially, this vision points to Christ: the living glory entering the temple anticipates Christ's presence in the New Covenant, where He becomes the true temple and sacrifice. The altar's precise measurements, while symbolic, foreshadow Christ's atoning work as the foundation of the Church. Thus, believers are called to live holy lives, recognizing that Christ's dwelling in the Spirit empowers them to avoid idolatry and actively participate in God's redemptive order, ensuring the sanctuary of their hearts remains consecrated and pure. (248 words)

Henry observes that Ezekiel 44 presents a profound theological framework centered on the exclusive access to God's presence through Christ, the true priest. The chapter's key imagery—particularly the shut gate (v. 2-3) and the purification rituals for the priests—reveals that only Christ, the "prince," enters heaven by His own holiness and righteousness, not by human merit. This gate remains closed to all unclean hearts, emphasizing that no human can approach God's sanctuary without being cleansed through Christ's blood and the power of His grace. The detailed instructions for the Levites—wearing linen garments, avoiding wool, abstaining from wine, and teaching distinction between holy and profane—symbolize Christ's sinless ministry and His role as the sole mediator who reconciles the unclean to God. Theologically, this underscores that true holiness is not achieved through ritualistic adherence but through Christ's work, which purifies the heart and enables access to God's presence. Practically, it warns believers against religious compromise: church leadership must embody spiritual purity, avoiding self-indulgence and maintaining doctrinal integrity to prevent defilement of God's sanctuary. Christ's fulfillment of this vision—being the only one who enters by His own holiness (v. 2) and who provides the only valid access—means that believers must rely on His blood for cleansing and His righteousness for ministry, rather than human efforts. This chapter challenges modern churches to prioritize Christ-centered purity, ensuring that leadership and worship honor God's holiness without compromising the sanctity of His presence.

Calvin's commentary on Ezekiel 44 emphasizes God's exclusive holiness and the necessity of thorough purification for access to His presence. He observes that the shut east gate symbolizes Christ's exclusive entry into the divine sanctuary—only the Lord Himself "enters by it," signifying that true access to God is mediated solely through Christ, not human merit. Calvin highlights the detailed rituals for the purified priests (Ezekiel 44:11–27), where linen garments, no wool, and specific cleansing protocols reflect the profound spiritual purification required by God's holiness. These rules, Calvin argues, are not mere ritualistic constraints but profound theological statements: they reveal that true worship demands an inner transformation, where the heart must be "uncircumcised" (Ezekiel 44:9), free from idolatry and sin. Crucially, Calvin connects this to Christ's role as the sole mediator. The Levites' restoration to priestly duties after purification prefigures how Christ, the true high priest, enters the heavenly sanctuary once for all (Hebrews 9:12), offering His blood as the only perfect atonement. Practically, Calvin stresses that believers must actively examine their hearts, ensuring their worship aligns with Christ's purity—not external conformity but genuine holiness. This calls for daily self-examination, avoiding ritualism without spiritual renewal, and living in the "sanctified" state Christ achieved through His sacrifice. The prohibition against wine (Ezekiel 44:21) further underscores that Christ's blood alone cleanses from sin, while the priests' exclusive right to the firstfruits (Ezekiel 44:30) illustrates that true spiritual blessing flows through Christ's mediation, not human effort. Thus, Calvin's summary reveals that God's sanctuary access is secured only through Christ's perfect work, demanding believers pursue inner purification to stand before Him. (278 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Ezekiel 44 reveals profound theological insights through the prophet's vision of the shut east gate. Poole interprets this gate as exclusively reserved for the high priest (or prince), symbolizing God's exclusive access to His holy presence through Christ. The gate's closure, declared by God Himself, signifies that only the authorized representative—here, the high priest—may enter, emphasizing that divine communion requires purification and proper standing. Poole notes the visible glory filling the temple, highlighting God's active presence where true worship occurs. The commentary powerfully warns against allowing "strangers," particularly those "uncircumcised in heart and flesh"—idolaters or spiritually unclean individuals—to infiltrate the sanctuary, as this pollutes worship and breaks covenant. Poole stresses that the people's failure to guard sacred spaces by appointing unfit keepers for holy things resulted in profaning God's name. Theologically, this underscores that true holiness requires internal and external purity; the sanctuary is not merely physical but a symbol of the believer's spiritual condition. Practically, this calls believers to vigilance against spiritual compromise: avoiding religious syncretism, ensuring leadership integrity, and guarding the church from unclean influences. Crucially, Poole connects this to Christ—His role as the ultimate High Priest who "entered once for all" (Hebrews 9:24), fulfilling the gate's purpose by providing the only sinless access to God. This vision warns against the modern tendency to permit unclean elements into sacred spaces, urging believers to maintain spiritual purity and recognize that Christ's unique mediation ensures true worship without pollution. (249 words)

Barnes's commentary on Ezekiel 44 reveals a profound theological framework where the temple's access rules serve as a mirror for spiritual purity and divine sovereignty. He emphasizes that the prince's exclusive right to enter the priests' court (Ezek. 44:1-3) symbolizes Christ as the ultimate representative, uniquely positioned to partake in the holy presence—distinct from earthly rulers, pointing to the Messiah's superior role. The chapter's central warning against "strangers uncircumcised in heart and flesh" entering the sanctuary (Ezek. 44:7-9) underscores the critical need for genuine spiritual transformation, not merely ritual compliance, as idolatry and false priesthood corrupt the temple's sacred purpose. Barnes connects this to Christ's high priesthood, noting that only those who faithfully minister—like the purified Levites (Ezek. 44:11-16)—can approach God's presence, directly typifying believers who are spiritually cleansed through Christ. The meticulous priestly regulations (Ezek. 44:17-21) further highlight the necessity of holiness in service, where linen garments symbolize purity and the prohibition against wool signifies a rejection of worldly uncleanness. Theologically, this passage affirms that true worship requires both external obedience and internal renewal, with the sanctuary's integrity dependent on the community's commitment to Christ. Practically, it challenges believers to examine their spiritual "uncircumcision"—avoiding compromise with worldly practices and ensuring their service reflects Christ-like purity. Christologically, the temple's restoration through the Messiah's people prefigures how Christ alone provides the true access to God, fulfilling the Old Testament's covenant while revealing the ongoing need for believers to maintain spiritual holiness in their worship and service. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Ezekiel 45 presents this chapter as a profound prophetic vision of God's ideal order for His people, intricately weaving earthly land divisions with cosmic theological truths. Henry emphasizes that the meticulously specified holy portion of land (52,000 x 10,000 cubits) serves as a symbolic foundation for the priesthood and Levitical ministry, foreshadowing Christ as the eternal High Priest who offers himself as the ultimate sacrifice. Crucially, Henry connects the chapter's detailed rituals—particularly the passover observance described in verses 21-22 and the subsequent feasts—to Christ's person and work. The lamb sacrificed for the passover becomes the direct symbol of Christ, the sinless Lamb of God whose blood reconciles humanity to God, while the seven-day feast mirrors Christ's ongoing intercessory ministry. Theophatically, Henry sees the "just balances" (v.10) and precise measurements as a call for ethical integrity in leadership and worship, reflecting God's demand for justice and righteousness. Practically, this commentary urges believers to actively pursue justice in their communities (as the princes are commanded to cease oppression), cultivate genuine worship (the unleavened bread of sincerity), and participate in the Lord's Supper as the memorial of Christ's sacrificial atonement. For modern Christians, this vision challenges us to live holy lives of reconciliation, grounded in the reality that Christ's finished work secures our redemption and sustains our fellowship with God through the ongoing presence of the Spirit.

John Calvin's commentary on Ezekiel 45 emphasizes this chapter as a profound covenantal vision revealing God's meticulous provision for justice and worship within His restored community. Calvin interprets the detailed land allocations—specifically the holy portion for priests, Levites, and the people—as a divine blueprint for ordered spiritual life. Theologically, this structure underscores Christ's unique priesthood: the "holy portion" (52,000 reeds by 10,000) symbolizes Christ's exclusive role as the eternal high priest who mediates access to God (Hebrews 4:14), while the Levitical portion (for 20 chambers) points to Christ's ministry through the Church. Calvin highlights the chapter's core message—verses 9–10—where God commands princes to cease oppression and embrace justice, directly foreshadowing Christ's redemptive work as the ultimate reconciler. Practically, Calvin urges believers to model this justice: rejecting economic exploitation, ensuring fair measurements (the "just balances" and "just ephah"), and actively participating in communal reconciliation, mirroring the prince's role in offering sacrifices for the community's sins. Christologically, the lamb sacrifices (verse 15) and the precise Temple rituals (verses 18–25) prefigure Christ's perfect atonement—the once-for-all sacrifice that fulfills the Old Covenant's demands, abolishing the need for repeated offerings. Calvin concludes that this vision calls the church to live with Christ as the true "prince" who reconciles all things through His blood, urging practical, sacrificial leadership in pursuit of divine justice and harmony within the body of Christ. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Ezekiel 45 provides a meticulous analysis of the land allocations for the restored Israelite community, emphasizing God's sovereign ordering of sacred space. Poole clarifies that the "holy portion" of land—measured at 25,000 by 10,000 cubits—is deliberately set apart *first* for God's dwelling, reflecting the foundational principle that divine presence must precede human settlement. He resolves the debate over reeds versus cubits, favoring cubits to ensure practical feasibility, noting this holy space (roughly 12 miles by 5 miles) serves as the exclusive territory for the sanctuary, priests, and Levites. Theologically, Poole underscores this division as a profound symbol: the land represents God's active sovereignty in reclaiming His people, while the "holy portion" explicitly prefigures Christ as the true Temple—where the divine presence dwells eternally through the person of Jesus. This allocation reveals God's intimate care for His people's needs (priests' dwellings, Levites' service) while maintaining strict separation between the sacred and profane. Practically, it challenges believers to prioritize God's kingdom before personal possessions, as the holy portion was allocated *before* the city or other lands. For modern readers, Poole's insights highlight that true worship requires intentional space for Christ—where God's presence is the central reality, not just a symbolic structure. This divine ordering calls us to live in alignment with Christ's lordship, ensuring that our lives and communities reflect the priority of the sacred over the secular, with Christ Himself as the ultimate "holy portion" where God dwells. (248 words)

Barnes's commentary on Ezekiel 45 reveals this chapter as a profound symbolic framework for spiritual reality rather than literal land division. The "holy portion" of 25,000 by 10,000 reeds for the priests represents God's exclusive claim on sacrificial devotion, while the Levites' and city portions illustrate the necessary interdependence of God's people. Theologically, this land allocation transcends physical territory to embody divine order: the prince's secure strip prevents oppression (echoing Jeremiah's warnings against tyranny), symbolizing Christ's authority that ends injustice. Barnes emphasizes the meticulous measurements—just balances, weights, and standardized offerings—pointing to Christ as the ultimate standard of righteousness. The "oblation" described here, a sixth part of barley and wheat, becomes a powerful Christ connection: it prefigures the New Covenant where Christ's sacrifice is the true, sufficient offering for reconciliation, fulfilling the Mosaic system's incomplete rituals. Practically, this text challenges believers to embrace justice in leadership (removing "exactions"), ensure honest worship practices, and understand that true worship involves sacrificial giving aligned with God's standards. The chapter's enduring relevance lies in its call for the church to mirror Christ's role as both the perfect sacrifice and the just ruler who liberates the oppressed, urging modern communities to prioritize relational equity and uncompromising integrity in their stewardship of God's kingdom. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Ezekiel 46 reveals profound theological connections between ancient temple rituals and Christ-centered reality. He emphasizes that the specific ordinances governing the prince's worship at the east gate—opening on Sabbaths and new moons, with prescribed burnt and peace offerings—serve as divine instructions for consistent, accessible worship without ritualistic burden. The east gate's symbolism points toward Christ's resurrection (the rising sun) and the promise of restoration. Critically, Henry interprets the daily burnt offerings (lamb and meat offerings) not as repetitive demands but as a perpetual foreshadowing of Christ's single, sufficient sacrifice—his blood purchased eternal redemption and ongoing intercession. The detailed rules concerning the prince's inheritance gifts highlight God's concern for justice: inheritance passes to sons by right, but servants receive temporary provision, reflecting Christ's ultimate claim on believers' lives while securing their eternal inheritance. Practically, this teaches Christians to maintain regular, humble worship without anxiety (like the daily offerings), understand that Christ's atoning work fully covers sin and reconciliation, and trust God's provision for their spiritual and earthly needs—avoiding both ritualistic anxiety and the oppression of sin. The passage thus underscores that Christ's work fulfills the temple rituals, making all worship and provision secure through him alone. (248 words)

John Calvin's commentary on Ezekiel 46 reveals profound theological insights through the meticulous details of temple rituals. Calvin emphasizes that the east gate's opening only on sabbaths and new moons signifies God's specific timing for divine communion, reflecting the sacred rhythm of worship where human access to the divine is carefully ordered. The prince's ritual entry, with priests preparing offerings at the gate threshold, illustrates Christ's role as the mediator who brings believers into God's presence through the atoning work of the Lamb. Calvin interprets the daily burnt offerings—lamb and meal offerings—as a perpetual foreshadowing of Christ's singular, eternal sacrifice, where the repeated ritual points to the sufficiency of Christ's once-for-all atonement. The intricate rules governing the prince's inheritance (Ezekiel 46:16–18) underscore Calvin's conviction that true leadership must prioritize justice and the preservation of familial inheritance, avoiding oppression—echoing Christ's call to stewardship and care for the vulnerable. Practically, Calvin urges believers to internalize this order: worship must be conducted with reverence and precision, mirroring the temple's disciplined structure to avoid chaos in spiritual life. The spatial arrangement of the courts also highlights Christ's centrality—where sacrifices are prepared and purified, the true Temple is the Church, and the believer's life should be a sanctuary of holiness. Thus, Ezekiel 46, in Calvin's view, serves as a timeless reminder that proper worship, ethical leadership, and Christ-centered order are essential for the community to reflect God's kingdom. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on Ezekiel 46 reveals a meticulously ordered system of worship rituals centered on the east gate of the inner court. Poole emphasizes that this gate, symbolizing access to the divine presence, remains shut on working days but opens on sabbaths and new moons—days of holy service—highlighting that true worship occurs only during God's designated holy times. The prince's ritual entry, where he stands at the threshold while priests prepare his burnt and peace offerings, underscores the profound theological insight that the greatest among us must humble themselves before God, reverencing His presence without claiming authority. Poole interprets the prince's posture—bowing at the threshold, not entering further—signifying that faith requires sufficient understanding without overreaching; the threshold represents the boundary where human worship meets divine holiness. The specific sacrifices (six lambs, a ram, etc.) and precise measurements for meat offerings and oil reflect the meticulous covenant order, yet Poole consistently points to Christ as their fulfillment: the gate symbolizes Christ as the sole access to God, the sacrifices prefigure His atoning death, and the requirement for the prince to exit the same way he entered reveals the need for consistent, Christ-centered submission rather than self-reliance. Practically, this commentary teaches that worship must be orderly, timed by God's holy days, and grounded in proper posture—acknowledging our need for reconciliation without presumption. It calls believers to approach God through Christ's finished work, understanding that true worship flows from faith that remains at the threshold of grace, where Christ's sacrifice provides the only adequate access to the Father.

Barnes interprets Ezekiel 46 as a vivid vision of restored worship order symbolizing God's renewed covenant community. The eastern gate rituals—where the prince enters to offer sacrifices before the priests, followed by the people's worship on sabbaths and new moons—reveal a theocratic structure where king, priest, and people collectively participate in worship without hierarchy or corruption. Theologically, this scene prefigures Christ as the ultimate high priest who mediates between God and humanity, with the prince's role mirroring Christ's authority as the "way" (John 14:6) while the sacrifices point to Christ's atoning work. Barnes emphasizes that the detailed offerings—six lambs and a ram on Sabbaths, a bullock on new moons—exceed Mosaic law requirements, signifying heightened devotion under the new covenant and the willingness of believers to give sacrificially. Practically, this commentary urges leaders to model Christ-like humility and justice: the prince's prohibition against oppressing the people (Ezekiel 46:18) calls for pastors to safeguard the poor and prevent exploitation, while the gate's symbolic order reminds communities of proper worship structure and mutual accountability. Christologically, the vision underscores that true worship occurs when the community aligns with God's authority, as the prince's sacrifice precedes his departure—a foreshadowing of Christ's death and resurrection. This passage thus challenges modern churches to cultivate leadership that balances sacrificial service with equitable justice, ensuring worship remains a communal act of reconciliation rather than hierarchical control. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Ezekiel 47 presents the river flowing from the Temple as a profound metaphor for the gospel's life-giving power and Christ's redemptive work. Henry identifies Christ himself as the living Temple and the source of these waters, emerging from his pierced side—symbolizing how the gospel flows from Jesus' sacrificial death into the world. The progressive depth of the waters—first to the ankles, then knees, loins, and finally a river—illustrates the spiritual journey: starting with foundational faith, deepening through grace, and culminating in the transformative power of the Holy Spirit that heals both physical and spiritual wounds. This river, which "shall be healed" and brings "a very great multitude of fish," represents the universal redemption Christ accomplishes, where all who believe find sustenance and healing. Henry emphasizes that this flow extends to the sea, signifying the gospel's global reach and the promise of eternal life for all who enter its waters. The land division described reflects the New Covenant's inclusivity, where believers—whether native or "strangers"—inherit the land equally through Christ, embodying God's grace that transcends tribal or ethnic boundaries. Practically, this calls believers to embrace the gospel's simplicity initially, seek deeper spiritual understanding through the Holy Spirit's guidance, and actively participate in God's healing work by sharing Christ's truth and mercy. Crucially, Henry connects the entire vision to Christ as the true Temple and Mediator, reminding us that the river's life-giving power originates solely in Jesus, urging churches today to be conduits of healing and inclusion, where all who come to Christ find both spiritual nourishment and a rightful place in God's eternal inheritance. (248 words)

Calvin interpreted Ezekiel 47 as a profound vision of God's restoring grace through Christ, emphasizing the river's life-giving power as a divine metaphor for the Church's spiritual provision. He saw the progressive measurement—water rising to ankles, knees, loins—symbolizing the gradual purification and spiritual growth believers experience through Christ's redemptive work, where the "healed waters" represent the Spirit's transformative power healing brokenness and enabling flourishing. Crucially, Calvin connected this river to Christ himself as the "living water" (John 7:38), whose mission flows from the sanctuary (the cross) to the sea (the world), bringing healing and abundance to all who believe. The vision of the land divided among tribes and foreigners highlights God's inclusive grace: Christ's work ensures that all who enter His kingdom—strangers and natives alike—become heirs to the land of blessing, reflecting the Church's role in extending restoration to the nations. Practically, Calvin urged believers to become conduits of this healing, actively participating in communities where spiritual renewal flows from Christ, just as the river nourishes diverse life. This vision calls Christians to embrace diversity within the body of Christ, recognizing that God's promise of inheritance extends to all who belong to Him through faith, not by ethnic or social boundaries. The river's journey from the sanctuary to the sea exemplifies the Gospel's universal reach, where Christ's healing power enables a thriving, life-giving community that honors God's covenant with Israel and the world.

Matthew Poole's commentary on Ezekiel 47 presents the vision of waters flowing from the temple as a profound spiritual typology. Poole emphasizes that the water originates beneath the temple threshold, symbolizing divine purification through Christ's sacrifice—replacing the physical purification of temple rituals with the spiritual cleansing of believers. The water's progressive depth (from ankles to loins) illustrates the gradual spiritual growth and increasing influence of God's grace in the life of the believer, moving from initial faith to deeper discipleship. Crucially, Poole connects the river's journey to the sea as a promise of redemption: the waters heal the "deserts" (spiritual barrenness and sin) that Christ's work transforms into "lands of waters and gardens." This vision directly points to Christ as the living source of this life-giving water (John 7:38), whose sacrifice initiates the spiritual renewal that flows from the temple (prefiguring Christ's presence) to heal the brokenness of creation. Theologically, Poole underscores that the waters represent the Holy Spirit's work—purifying, sustaining, and restoring—whereas the deserts symbolize the spiritual deadness of sinners before Christ. Practically, this calls believers to cultivate the "trees" (faith, hope, love) along the spiritual river of their lives, actively participating in the work of healing their communities and the world through Christ-centered living. The vision thus affirms that true spiritual abundance flows from Christ's atoning work, urging believers to trust in His promise to transform their inner deserts into thriving gardens of God's presence. (248 words)

Barnes' commentary on Ezekiel 47 presents this vision as a profound theological metaphor for God's redemptive work, where a river flowing from the temple courtyard symbolizes the Holy Spirit's life-giving power. Theologically, the waters' progressive deepening—from ankle to loins to a swimmable river—illustrates the spiritual growth of the Church, from initial baptismal renewal (Ezekiel 47:3) to the universal outpouring of the Spirit at Pentecost (Ezekiel 47:4) and ultimately to the Church's expansive, healing mission. The river's journey to the Dead Sea, where it "heals" the waters, signifies Christ's transformative power—reconciling the broken (the Dead Sea, representing spiritual desolation) and enabling life where death reigned. This healing water directly connects to Jesus' promise that "he who drinks of this water will have living water" (John 4:14), pointing to the New Covenant where sin's consequences are reversed. Practically, this vision challenges believers to cultivate deep spiritual intimacy (like the waters rising to the loins), actively participate in the Church's mission to bring healing and abundance to barren places, and understand that true spiritual vitality flows from God's sovereign provision, not human effort. The land inheritance described (Ezekiel 47:13–14) further underscores that God's promise of restoration for His people—especially through Christ—will be fulfilled in the coming age, where the Church becomes the "healed" river nourishing all nations. This commentary thus affirms that Christ's work in the Spirit's outpouring is the source of enduring life, calling believers to live as channels of this healing power in a broken world. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on Ezekiel 48 presents the land divisions as a profound symbolic vision revealing God's eternal plan for the church in Christ. Henry emphasizes that this detailed layout—where the holy oblation (the priestly portion) is precisely defined, the city is surrounded by suburbs, and gates are named after tribes—functions not as a historical map but as a spiritual blueprint for the redeemed community. Theologically, Henry interprets the "holy oblation" of 52,000 by 10,000 cubits as a prefiguration of Christ himself, the perfect sacrifice and dwelling place where God's presence is made accessible. The city's name, "The LORD is there," directly points to Christ's promise of indwelling grace and the New Covenant where "the Lord is there" for all believers, transcending tribal boundaries. Practically, Henry urges Christians to recognize their identity as citizens of this holy city—where Christ's presence is real and active—rather than being defined by earthly divisions. This demands holy living, stewardship of God's gifts, and communal worship that reflects the unity of the church. Crucially, Henry connects the vision to Christ's role as the true "holy oblation," the one who reconciles all tribes (people) through his sacrifice, making the entire church the living temple where God dwells. Believers are thus called to live in the reality of Christ's presence, actively participating in the city's life while understanding their inheritance is secured through him alone—inviting all to experience the transformative truth that "the Lord is there" in the community of faith. (248 words)

Calvin's commentary on Ezekiel 48 reveals this chapter as a profound typological framework for understanding God's redemptive plan, not a literal land division. He emphasizes that the detailed allocation of territory among Israel's tribes—particularly the "holy oblation" (52,000 by 52,000) centered on the sanctuary—symbolizes Christ's atoning work and the New Covenant. For Calvin, this "holy oblation" represents the atoning sacrifice of Christ, where the sanctuary in the midst signifies Christ's mediatorial role as the true Temple. The priests (sons of Zadok) who maintain this holy space point to Christ's unique priesthood, while the land's boundaries and the city's gates named after tribes illustrate God's universal provision and the Church's unity under Christ. Theologically, Calvin stresses that this vision transcends physical inheritance, revealing God's promise of restoration for His people through Christ.
